_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



It is Carpenter Co.'s intention is to maintain a safe and healthful working environment for all its employees.  In order to meet Carpenter Co.'s goals all management and hourly employees are held responsible for our Safety and Health Program.  To empower our people communicating policies and procedures along with training are two important elements of our program.  Auditing, investigating incidents and taking corrective measures to prevent future mishaps are the tools used to maintain our programs.  Our Chairman of the Board and CEO has set the standard for Carpenter Co. in the corporate safety and health policy which he signed.   

                                                                                                                                                         THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES                                                      



To control accidental releases our company has a PM system in place to check all equipment that could cause a release or other problems.  These PMs are monitored annually by our corporate Engineering Department.  In addition to the monitoring of the PM's, Corporate annually have the Health, Safety and Environmental departments conduct audits.  These audits are in addition to departmental monthly audits.

                                                                                                                           

 Prior to start-up a pre-start check of equipment is conducted by the employees and during a pour the computer system monitors chemical flow and if a flow problem is detected the system shuts down.  In addition to the hardware monitoring the pouring team monitors the process closely and if a problem arises then they can take the appropriate action to prevent a release.  When a railcar or tanker is being unloaded it is being monitored by the Chemical Unloader and Pouring Clerk via TV the computerized pumping system monitors

valve openings and the storage tank levels. 



Ninety percent of the work force in the department is a part of our HazMat team.  This team receives annual eight hour refresher training, first aid training.  The team conducts drills with realistic problems.  The drills are critiqued and the necessary adjustments are made to improve the team's skill level.  In addition to the full blown drills, minor drills are conducted in the form of table top drills and dress out drills.                                                                                                    



It is the policy of Carpenter Co. - Tupelo Division in the case of a spill to first evacuate the department and secure the perimeter then plan the task and assign duties.  Our HazMat team will only control and stop the release if it is minor.  When the conditions exceed our capabilities we call the Tupelo Fire Department - HazMat Unit and if necessary an approved outside environmental emergency response contractor will be call to clean up.  The HazMat team has people assigned to make the necessary calls to the proper agencies for reporting reasons, emergency response, supplies, financing, etc.,. These jobs would be conduct as directed by the Incident commander.     









HANDLING OF REGULATTED SUBSTANCE     

                                                                                                               

The primary activity at Carpenter Co. - Tupelo Division is the manufacturing of polyurethane foam for the furniture industry.  The main ingredient of foam is TDI, which is regulated and requires us to have a risk management plan (RMP) in place.  This facility can have around 2,000,000 lbs of TDI on site at one time.      



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM    



In the event of an accidental release of our TDI we are required under the Clean Air Act 40 CFR 68 to have a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in place to first prevent a relapse through training, assessing haz

ards, correcting potential hazards through PMs and by improving our process.  In addition to the RMP we have developed an Integrated Contingency Plan, which handles fire, chemical spills, threats against the company or employees, severe weather, personal injury emergencies to comply with:  Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (CERCLA), the Superfund Amendment and Reauthorization Act (SARA), the Risk Management Program regulations, the Clean Water Act (CWA), the Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) requirements, Spill Prevention Countermeasures and Control (SPCC) regulations, the Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (Hazwoper) standard, the OSHA Emergency Action Plan standard, and the Mississippi Comprehensive Waste Minimization Program (CWMP).   

                                                                                                                                                                        In addition to our emergency response systems there are physical barriers to contain the TDI and maintain the substance on site where it can be neutralized and removed.  If all else fails our employees are trained to handle releases safety and to involve the community agencies to protect the general population.    

                                                                                                                                                             Carpenter Co. feels that a proactive approach to prevent a release is better for all; therefore we maintain a PM system to catch problems before they can happen and look at alternative substances that are more environmental friendly.    

                                                                                                                                                                     THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY  



There have not been any spills of TDI in the past five

-years.   



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM       



Our Emergency Response team receives annual 8 hour refresher Hazwoper training, American Red Cross First Aid training.  The team has a spill drill with a realistic problem annually.  The drill is critiqued and the members of the team work on a correction plan to improve equipment and procedures.  The team will periodically have table top drills or dress out drills during the year.   



The Incident Command Team has an organizational structure that has jobs assigned with alternates, but the HazMat team is trained to do all the related duties in case they are short personnel.  The Incident Commander has people to control the entry, data collect, notify agencies, emergency services, supplies, fiances, etc.                                                                                                                                                                                Our entry team would only handles minor releases, where they can control and stop the release.  Once the release exceeds our capabilities the Tupelo Fire Department-HazMat Unit would be called and an approved outside environment emergency response contractor brought on site to clean and remove the spill substance.  A copy of our Integrated Contingency Plan has been given to the Tupleo Hospital, Lee County Sheriffs Department, the Verona Fire Department, and Lee County Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  In an actual significant release the LEPC would be notified to help coordinate emergency services and notification of the local population.
